incidentEng: Napoleon was born in Ajaccio

img.imgDescriptionEng: Napoleon Bonaparte was born in this house
His Father Carl Bonapart (1746 - 1785) and his mother Maria Letizia Ramolino (1750 - 1836)
Bonaparte's Family Tree

incidentEng: Napoleon made his first trip to France

img.imgDescriptionEng: Young Napoleon Bonaparte in Ajaccio, Corsica, portrayed in a childhood scene (19th-century artistic interpretation).

incidentEng: Napoleon was admitted on January 1st to the College of Autun in Burgundy.

img.imgDescriptionEng: “The historic Collège d’Autun, attended by a young Napoleon Bonaparte in 1779.”

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte entered the École Militaire de Brienne

img.imgDescriptionEng: Napoleon Bonaparte as a youth at the Brienne Military Academy (1779).
Young Napoleon Bonaparte studying during his school years, symbolically portrayed with a large shadow representing his future influence over Europe.
École Militaire de Brienne

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte entered the Royal Military School in Paris.

img.imgDescriptionEng: École Militaire de Paris, Napoleon’s next school after Brienne

incidentEng: Carlo Buonaparte, the father of Napoleon Bonaparte, died in Montpellier, leaving the family in financial difficulty.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Carlo Maria Buonaparte (1746-1785)
A later artistic depiction of Napoleon Bonaparte as a Second Lieutenant of Artillery in 1785.

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte graduated from the École Militaire de Paris and was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant of Artillery.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Napoleon at about 16 years old, depicted as an artillery lieutenant.

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte began his service in Valence as a Second Lieutenant in the La Fère Artillery Regiment.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Napoleon Bonaparte as a young Second Lieutenant stationed in Valence (1785–1786)
Young Napoleon reading while stationed in Valence in 1786. Illustrating his dedication to study during early military service.

img.incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte began his service as a Second Lieutenant in the La Fère Artillery Regiment, later stationed in Valence.

incidentEng: Young Napoleon Bonaparte returned to Corsica on his first leave

img.imgDescriptionEng: The Birthplace of Napoleon in Ajaccio, Corsica

incidentEng: Lieutenant Bonaparte returned to France and resumed active military service at Auxonne.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Lieutenant Napoleon Bonaparte studying during his posting in Auxonne (1788–1791), where he devoted himself to artillery science, mathematics, and military strategy

incidentEng: Young Napoleon participated in maintaining order during food and tax-related riots in the Valence region amid rising revolutionary tensions.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Storming of the Bastille marked the symbolic beginning of the French Revolution.

incidentEng: As an artillery officer, Napoleon was involved in security duties in the Dauphiné area during early unrest of the French Revolution.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Representation of the revolutionary assault on the Bastille prison in Paris. (14 July 1789)

incidentEng: The Storming of the Bastille marked the symbolic beginning of the French Revolution.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Revolutionaries assaulting the Bastille
Revolutionaries assaulting the Bastille
Revolutionaries assaulting the Bastille

incidentEng: Napoleon returned to Corsica and became involved in local revolutionary politics in Corsica.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Napoleon returned to Corsica to engage in local revolutionary politics, motivated by his Corsican nationalism, his admiration for Pasquale Paoli, and the opportunities created by the French Revolution.

Pasquale Paoli (1725-1807), the Corsican nationalist leader. Initially admired by young Napoleon, their political differences during the French Revolution led to a break, forcing the Bonaparte family to flee Corsica in 1793.

incidentEng: Young Napoleon returned to his artillery regiment in Auxonne after his involvement in Corsican politics.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Illustration of the Auxonne barracks and military grounds where Napoleon Bonaparte served as an artillery officer between 1788 and 1791. This location was central to his early development in artillery tactics and military theory.

incidentEng: Napoleon was promoted to First Lieutenant in the La Fère Artillery Regiment while serving in Auxonne.

img.imgDescriptionEng: On 1 June 1791, Young Napoleon was promoted to First Lieutenant in the La Fère Artillery Regiment while serving in Auxonne, marking an important step in his early career during the French Revolutionary period.

incidentEng: Young Napoleon returned to his artillery regiment in Auxonne after his involvement in Corsican politics.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Illustration of the Auxonne barracks and military grounds where Napoleon Bonaparte served as an artillery officer between 1788 and 1791. This location was central to his early development in artillery tactics and military theory.

incidentEng: Following his promotion to First Lieutenant on 1 June 1791 in Auxonne, Napoleon was transferred to the 4th Artillery Regiment in Valence.

img.incidentEng: Mural depicting Napoleon Bonaparte in 1791, in Valence.

incidentEng: Napoleon joined a battalion of the National Guard in Ajaccio and became involved in local revolutionary conflicts in Corsica.

img.incidentEng: Napoleon joined the National Guard in Ajaccio and became involved in local political and military clashes because he supported the French Revolutionary cause and opposed rival Corsican nationalist factions, leading to violent confrontations in his hometown.

incidentEng: The War of the First Coalition began as revolutionary France faced a coalition of European monarchies including Austria, Prussia, Britain, Spain, and others. Napoleon, then a young artillery officer, participated in early campaigns that laid the foundation for his military rise.

img.incidentEng: Illustration showing the major participants and territorial alignment during the War of the First Coalition (1792–1797), with revolutionary France in blue and the anti‑French coalition states in red).
The Battle of Valmy, also known as the Cannonade of Valmy, was the first major victory by the army of France during the Revolutionary Wars that followed the French Revolution. (20 September 1792)

The Invasion of France (Battle of Quiberon) was a landing by royalist émigré troops on 23 June to support the Chouannerie and Vendée Revolt, aiming to end the French Revolution and restore the monarchy. The invasion failed and dealt a severe blow to the royalist cause by 21 July. (1795)

incidentEng: Napoleon returned to Paris from Corsica to continue his military and political career amid the revolutionary turmoil in France.
Napoleon was reinstated in the army with the rank of Captain and sent to Ajaccio.
King Louis XVI was executed by guillotine in Paris on 21 January 1793 after being found guilty of treason during the French Revolution.

img.imgdesc: Depiction of King Louis XVI’s execution by guillotine at the Place de la Révolution in Paris on 21 January 1793 during the French Revolution.
The moment of Louis XVI’s execution in Paris, an event that marked a decisive turning point in the French Revolution and the abolition of the monarchy.
Escorted by revolutionary guards, Louis XVI (1754-1793) approaches the guillotine in Paris, marking the final act of the Bourbon king during the French Revolution.

incidentEng: After a political break with Pasquale Paoli and the looting of the Bonaparte family home by Paoli’s supporters, Napoleon fled Corsica with his family

img.imgdesc: Accused by supporters of Pasquale Paoli of being too pro-French, young Napoleon and his family were forced to flee their home in Corsica.
Illustration of the Bonaparte family leaving their ancestral home in Corsica after Pasquale Paoli’s supporters ransacked the Casa Buonaparte in June 1793.

incidentEng: After fleeing Corsica with his family following a political break with Pasquale Paoli, Napoleon rejoined his regiment in Nice while his family continued to Toulon.

In July 1793, Napoleon was stationed in Avignon with Republican forces to help retake the city from federalist rebels and participated in operations around the area while writing his political pamphlet Le Souper de Beaucaire.
Napoleon Bonaparte joined the Republican forces at Toulon on 29 August 1793.

img.imgdesc: Napoleon Bonaparte at the Siege of Toulon in 1793, showing his early leadership in Republican forces during the French Revolutionary Wars.
Illustration of Napoleon directing artillery at the Siege of Toulon, demonstrating his emerging tactical skills in 1793.
An early depiction of Napoleon in action during the Siege of Toulon, a key moment that propelled his military career forward.

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte joined the Republican forces at Toulon on 29 August 1793.

img.imgdesc: Napoleon Bonaparte at the Siege of Toulon in 1793, showing his early leadership in Republican forces during the French Revolutionary Wars.
Illustration of Napoleon directing artillery at the Siege of Toulon, demonstrating his emerging tactical skills in 1793.
An early depiction of Napoleon in action during the Siege of Toulon, a key moment that propelled his military career forward.

incidentEng: Napoleon developed artillery plans at Toulon, proposing the capture of key forts to secure the city against the British and Spanish forces.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Illustration depicting the Siege of Toulon (August–December 1793), a key early battle of the French Revolutionary Wars in which young artillery officer Napoleon Bonaparte played a decisive role in recapturing the strategic port from British, Spanish, and royalist forces

incidentEng: Napoleon developed artillery plans at Toulon, proposing the capture of key forts to secure the city against the British and Spanish forces.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Illustration depicting the Siege of Toulon (August–December 1793), a key early battle of the French Revolutionary Wars in which young artillery officer Napoleon Bonaparte played a decisive role in recapturing the strategic port from British, Spanish, and royalist forces

incidentEng: During the Reign of Terror in September 1793, Republican authorities intensified actions against federalist rebels in southern France. Napoleon, recently stationed in Avignon, continued to support military operations while witnessing the revolutionary government's harsh measures.

img.imgdesc: Execution by guillotine of nine émigrés in October 1793 during the Reign of Terror, showing revolutionary justice against perceived enemies of the Republic.
Execution by guillotine in the Place de la Révolution in Paris during the Reign of Terror in 1793–1794, showing the public execution of suspected counter‑revolutionaries.
Depiction of Maximilien Robespierre’s execution by guillotine in Paris on 28 July 1794, marking the fall of the leading figure of the Reign of Terror.

incidentEng: During the Reign of Terror in September 1793, Republican authorities intensified actions against federalist rebels in southern France.

img.imgdesc: Queen Marie Antoinette (1755-1793) being escorted from the Conciergerie to the guillotine in Paris on 16 October 1793 during the Reign of Terror, shortly before her execution.
Marie Antoinette after her execution by guillotine in Paris on 16 October 1793, capturing the final moments of the former queen during the Reign of Terror.
Depiction of Maximilien Robespierre’s execution by guillotine in Paris on 28 July 1794, marking the fall of the leading figure of the Reign of Terror.

incidentEng: Republican forces successfully recaptured Toulon from British, Spanish, and royalist control, securing the strategic port for revolutionary France.

img.imgdesc: Napoleon’s strategic skills at Toulon ensured the port’s recapture and marked the beginning of his rapid ascent in military ranks.

Depiction of the battlefield during the final phase of the Siege of Toulon (29 August – 19 December 1793), showing the intensity of the Republican assault that forced the Allied evacuation and the recapture of the strategic port city

Depiction of Napoleon Bonaparte on the battlefield, standing alongside his troops and directing military operations, illustrating his early leadership and tactical role during the French Revolutionary Wars.

incidentEng: Following the successful recapture of Toulon, Napoleon Bonaparte was promoted to Brigadier General (Général de brigade) at the age of 24, marking his first major military advancement.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Depiction of Napoleon Bonaparte at the Siege of Toulon (1793). He earned his promotion to Brigadier General through his innovative use of artillery, effectively targeting key forts and directing Republican forces, which led to the successful recapture of the port from British, Spanish, and royalist control.

img.imgdesc: Depiction of the battlefield during the final phase of the Siege of Toulon (29 August – 19 December 1793), showing the intensity of the Republican assault that forced the Allied evacuation and the recapture of the strategic port city

incidentEng: Maximilien Robespierre, leader of the Jacobins and key figure of the Reign of Terror, was arrested and executed on 27 July 1794 (9 Thermidor), marking the end of the Reign of Terror in France.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Portrait of Maximilien Robespierre (1758-1794), the influential Jacobin leader and figure of the Reign of Terror during the French Revolution.
Robespierre being captured and later taken to the guillotine during the Coup of 9 Thermidor, ending the radical phase of the French Revolution.

incidentEng: After the fall of Maximilien Robespierre and the collapse of the Jacobin regime on 27 July 1794 (9 Thermidor), Napoleon Bonaparte was arrested  due to his suspected association with the Robespierre brothers. He was detained and interrogated for about two weeks before being released without formal charges, though his military career was temporarily suspended.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Napoleon imprisoned in 1794 after the fall of the Jacobins, suspected of ties to the Robespierre brothers.

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte was released from detention after being arrested due to his suspected association with the Robespierre brothers. He faced no formal charges, but his military career remained temporarily suspended.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Depiction of Napoleon Bonaparte during his brief detention in 1794 following the fall of Robespierre at Fort Carré.

incidentEng: Napoleon Bonaparte was released from detention after being arrested due to his suspected association with the Robespierre brothers. He faced no formal charges, but his military career remained temporarily suspended.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Depiction of Napoleon Bonaparte during his brief detention in 1794 following the fall of Robespierre at Fort Carré.

incidentEng: Napoleon became briefly engaged to Désirée Clary, a merchant's daughter from Marseille. The engagement ended when she hesitated to move to Paris, but Napoleon remembered her fondly.

img.imgDescriptionEng: Desirée Clary (1777-1860) became engaged to Napoleon on April 21, 1795, but he broke the engagement off on September 6 when he became involved with Joséphine de Beauharnais. She freed him from his promise of marriage.

incidentEng: Napoleon was appointed commander of the forces to suppress the royalist uprising in Paris.
